awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Development of a learning community focused on sea-level rise and coastal habitat change
awd_abstract_narration:
Rising sea levels are affecting coastal shorelines by drowning marshes and sea water seeping into forests, farms, and cities along the coasts. Within this century rising sea water will affect 5% of the global population living along the coastline and 10% of the global gross domestic product. When combined with projected coastal wetland loss, rising sea levels will make communities more susceptible to flooding and economic disruptions.  Over the past decade, as coastal scientists have observed signs of increasing decline in coastal wetlands and maritime forests of the U.S. Northeast, the goal of coastal restoration projects has shifted almost completely towards adaptation to sea level rise. Coastal marshes play a key role in mitigating these effects of sea level rise but are themselves vulnerable to rising water. Fundamental research is needed to understand how sea level rise affects marshes and adjacent coastal areas and what can be done to make them more resilient. This EAGER award will provide novel and important insights into the processes responsible for coastal marsh die-off and potential mechanisms to enhance marsh resilience through expansion into adjacent forests and fields. Through field sampling and remote sensing this award will measure the means by which sea water rise affects both the marsh and adjacent forests and fields. An important and creative component of the research is the engagement of under-represented groups through the creation of a mentoring network focused on the proposed research.

This award has high potential for producing a transformative understanding of the effects of sea level rise on the resilience of coastal marsh systems in the northeastern US. Through a novel combination of insitu assessment of hydrologic stressors and remote sensing geospatial analyses, the award will assess the proximate hydrologic and ecological causes and consequences of sea level rise. By combining new technology (e.g., UAV flights, low cost pressure transducers, GEOBIA, machine learning algorithms), the research will provide a new understanding of how hydrologic factors drive coastal habitat transitions, which can provide important information on how interventions can be applied successfully to conserve coastal habitats for wildlife and flood mitigation values. In addition to understanding the factors responsible for marsh die off, a particularly unique aspect of this EAGER award is understanding the hydrologic and biogeochemical mechanisms by which transgression of the marsh into adjacent terrestrial systems occurs. The research takes a robust approach to understanding the temporal and spatial scales over which these processes occur. This award will develop an innovative mentoring network framework to engage under-served students in estuarine research. By taking a near-peer cohort approach to training the students will benefit from immersive funded research experiences and a supportive research community. The expansive training plan includes professional workshops, education workshops, and other professional enhancement activities (annual professional meetings, participation in professional networks).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This coupled education-research award advanced our understanding of salt marsh ecohydrology under climate change, and enhanced near-peer mentorship among high school, undergraduate, and graduate students supported by the award, to enhance achievement, particularly for members of target groups, including first generation college students, and those from under-represented or and/or under-resource backgrounds. Designed to be a two-year project, this project occurred over a 3.5 year period primarily due to COVID-related restrictions that prevented fieldwork during 2020.

Intellectual Merit—Studying ecohydrology in drowning coastal salt marshes and along the marsh-upland ecotone, our work has revealed critical factors influencing marsh resilience and ecosystem function. Our work has supported the paradigm shift that is occurring among scientists studying salt marshes, where traditionally marsh ecozones were ascribed by elevation (e.g., "high" and "low" marsh zones), whereas recent work has ascribed hydrologic zonation characterized by distance to tidal channel, which shapes exposure to root zone flooding. In addition, our work has characterized how these ecohydrologic zones are responding to climate change; including their association with die-back areas on the marsh platform, as well as through propagation of storm surges into coastal forests, as well as examining species responses to ecohydrologic zonation (Courtney et al., 2024; Cherneskie et al., in review). Our work has also focused on interventions designed to extend the lifespan of drowning marshes, such as ecohydrologic manipulations (Watson et al., 2022) and sediment placement (Wilburn et al., in press). Our work has provided a holistic understanding of the challenges and opportunities in coastal marsh ecosystem management, highlighting the need for interdisciplinary approaches that integrate hydrology, ecology, and restoration practices to ensure the long-term resilience of these vital ecosystems.

Publications include:

  1. Courtney, S., Montalto, F. and Watson, E.B., 2024. Climate and vegetation change in a coastal marsh: two snapshots of groundwater dynamics and tidal flooding at Piermont Marsh, NY spanning 20 years. Wetlands, 44(1)8. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13157-023-01761-9
  2. Watson, E.B., Ferguson, W., Champlin, L.K., White, J.D., Ernst, N., Sylla, H.A., Wilburn, B.P. and Wigand, C., 2022. Runnels mitigate marsh drowning in microtidal salt marshes. Frontiers in Environmental Science, 10, p.987246. doi: 10.3389/fenvs.2022.987246
  3. Wilburn, B., K. Raper, K.B. Raposa, A.B. Gray, T.J. Mozdzer, and E.B. Watson In Press. Promoting success in thin layer sediment placement: effects of sediment grain size and amendments on salt marsh plant growth and greenhouse gas exchange. Restoration Ecology.
  4. Cherneskie, K., D. Njie, L. Champlin, D. Swenson Perger, and E.B. Watson. [currently in re-review after submission of revisions] Soil drainage influences coastal salt marsh productivity and soils biogeochemistry. Aquatic Botany.

We also have permanently archived four datasets with Dryad, ensuring that data collected by this project is accessible in perpetuity.

  1. Development of a learning community focused on sea-level rise and coastal habitat change. [Dataset] Dryad. https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.ghx3ffbvz
  2. Promoting success in thin layer sediment placement: effects of sediment grain size and amendments on salt marsh plant growth and greenhouse gas exchange.  [Dataset] Dryad. https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.xsj3tx9nx
  3. Climate and vegetation change in a coastal marsh: two snapshots of groundwater dynamics and tidal flooding at Piermont Marsh, NY spanning 20 years. [Dataset] Dryad. https://doi.org/10.21203/rs.3.rs-3171581
  4. Drainage impacts on the productivity of the wetland species Spartina alterniflora and Salicornia pacifica. [Dataset]. Dryad. https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.5qfttdzc1

Broader Impacts—The broader impacts of this project include enhancing achievement for those from target backgrounds through establishment of near-peer mentorship practices, as well as enhancing informed coastal restoration practices. Mentorship - We provided opportunities for lab members to receive formal mentorship training, and offered online professional development and career exposure to participants in summer of 2020. We offered lab mentees, including high school and undergraduate students opportunities to receive research training, training in data analysis and bioinformatics in R, co-author and lead manuscripts, receive feedback on graduate school, job and fellowship applicants, participate in mock interviews, and receive introduction to our professional networks. All of the students we have trained, including many who are first generation college students and those from under-represented backgrounds have been retained within STEM, two mentees have received Fulbright awards (Cambodia, Fiji Islands), and several are pursuing graduate training. Outreach to stakeholders and managers- We have engaged with management and stakeholder audiences through the coproduction of science in collaboration with managers (e.g., Watson et al., 2022; Wilburn et al., in press), through public outreach and communication sessions such as presentations for the New Jersey DEP Wetlands Seminar, the Science and Technical Advisory Committee meetings for National Estuary Programs, and the informal "Research at the Reserve" series held by the Waquoit Bay National Estuarine Research Reserve.
